page.title: 08Farming, Warbleton
page.content: The land is mostly heavy clay and poorly drained, but areas of a fine Tunbridge Wells sand are found on many farms. Most farms are small family concerns employing at the most one outside worker, but there remains an unusually high proportion of tenanted and leased land at a time when most of the farmland of Britain has become owner occupied. The poor nature of the land has lead to a steady reduction of dairy farming with only some 5 herds remaining. The greater part is under permanent pasture used for beef and sheep production, but the better drained fields are cultivated for cereals. Either way production is poor by national levels and land values are only held up by non agrarian factors. There is an intensive poultry unit of some 50,000 broilers, an intensive pig unit of 100 sows and some horticulture
